coredata.dc:title: Bridging excellence, knowledge management and sustainability: Introducing the ‘Knowledge Management Excellence Model 21′, a model for sustainable development goals alignment
coredata.dc:creator: Barrantes-Briceño, Christian Eric
Almada Santos, Fernando César
Nagano, Marcelo Seido
coredata.dc:description: This paper aims to introduce a new sustainable business excellence model, called Knowledge Management Excellence Model 21 (KMEM21), a theoretical framework that combines Knowledge Management and Business Excellence Models (BEMs), proposing an approach applicable to organizations to directly contribute towards achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The paper through a qualitative-exploratory methodology makes an analysis and benchmarking, emphasizes the integration of Knowledge Management and three specific Business Excellence Models (Management Excellence Model (MEG) from Brazil, Baldrige Excellence Framework, and EFQM). This integration uncovers relationships between organizational concepts associated with Knowledge Management and BEMs, which contributes to new insights in the literature regarding these concepts' interplay. BEMs are presented as tools that can catalyze the power of Knowledge Management towards achieving SDGs. However, it's noted that the existing BEMs might not be adequate, as the goal extends beyond organizational improvement and excellence to encompass sustainable development aligned with SDGs. The article suggests that specific organizational concepts, identified through a literature review and aligned with Knowledge Management and BEMs, can be selected as indicators associated with the constructed KMEM21 and the SDGs. These indicators are intended to form a bridge between the new model and the SDGs. However, given the comprehensive nature of the theory, model development, application, result acquisition, and analysis, the article's primary contribution will be in its focus on elaborating the instrument and technique, demonstrating the creation of a theoretical framework for the SDGs. Future works will showcase the application of the proposed KMEM21 method in five Brazilian organizations, members of Global Compact, to compare the achieved objectives and the results obtained with the organizations' performance and their sustainability reports.

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: The SDGs are defined through a series of measurable targets, requiring substantial cooperation and global effort at various levels for monitoring (Caiado et al., 2018). They are closely integrated into the multi-year strategy of the United Nations Global Compact (UNGC) to promote awareness and corporate action in support of achieving the goals by 2030 (Edgeman, 2019). This includes a declaration of the 17 SDGs and 169 other targets, along with a section on monitoring and review mechanisms, means of implementation, and global partnerships (Caiado et al., 2018).Furthermore, the article highlights fresh components that enhance the applicability and utility of KMEM21 as a model for organizations striving to attain excellence in quality and sustainability, with a primary focus on leveraging Knowledge Management as the foundational support to reach the SDGs. The development of KMEM21 is based on the three previously mentioned BEMs, revealing a common construction among them. This construction was associated with the authors' acquired knowledge to explain the development of KMEM21. Following this reasoning, indicators were derived from the relationship between organizational concepts of KM and BEMs, forming the dimensions of KMEM21. Similarly, an analysis was conducted to relate these dimensions to the goals of each SDG.In 1980, the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), in collaboration with the World Wildlife Fund for Nature and the United Nations Environment Program, launched the World Conservation Strategy. This milestone represented the first significant advancement in integrating environmental and developmental concerns into a comprehensive concept of \u201Cconservation\u201D (Mebratu, 1998).Laurett and Mendes (2019) emphasize that achieving sustainable development requires strong leadership, clear strategic direction, human resource development, effective partnerships, and processes. Mohamed et al. (2009) identify four key factors in achieving healthier sustainable development, with knowledge management being the first. Although literature lacks a defined set of aspects supporting the relationship between KM and sustainability, Arduini et al. (2023) identify vision, strategy, action plan, knowledge processes, organizational structure, organizational effectiveness, and IT infrastructure as fundamental to the KM-sustainability relationship.The methodology of each of the three BEMs stands out for its uniqueness, presenting a distinct approach for each model that lacks parallels in the literature. The development of these models is based on the studies conducted by the institutions that sponsor and implement them (National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) for Malcolm Baldrige, EuropeanFoundation for Quality Management (EFQM) for EFQM, and National QualityFoundation (FNQ) for MEG). Each model has its own philosophy and keeps its development process internal, with only the final model being made public. For this reason, few sources offer insights into their development, and the closest sources of information are the websites and guides provided by these institutions.Furthermore, existing BEMs, along with their associated quality awards, can serve as motivational tools for organizations and employees to reach established goals. By adapting these models to incorporate sustainability and align with the SDGs, organizations can gain recognition for their contributions to sustainable development. BEMs, when integrated with sustainability goals, enhance the likelihood of successful goal attainment, promoting awareness and commitment to the 2030 Agenda.Funding: This work was financed in part by the Coordena\u00E7\u00E3o de Aperfei\u00E7oamento de Pessoal de N\u00EDvel Superior - Brazil (CAPES) - Finance Code 001, and partially supported by grants 312585/2021-7 and 404819/2023-0 from Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cient\u00EDfico e Tecnol\u00F3gico (CNPq), Brazil.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: This paper aims to introduce a new sustainable business excellence model, called Knowledge Management Excellence Model 21 (KMEM21), a theoretical framework that combines Knowledge Management and Business Excellence Models (BEMs), proposing an approach applicable to organizations to directly contribute towards achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The paper through a qualitative-exploratory methodology makes an analysis and benchmarking, emphasizes the integration of Knowledge Management and three specific Business Excellence Models (Management Excellence Model (MEG) from Brazil, Baldrige Excellence Framework, and EFQM). This integration uncovers relationships between organizational concepts associated with Knowledge Management and BEMs, which contributes to new insights in the literature regarding these concepts' interplay. BEMs are presented as tools that can catalyze the power of Knowledge Management towards achieving SDGs. However, it's noted that the existing BEMs might not be adequate, as the goal extends beyond organizational improvement and excellence to encompass sustainable development aligned with SDGs. The article suggests that specific organizational concepts, identified through a literature review and aligned with Knowledge Management and BEMs, can be selected as indicators associated with the constructed KMEM21 and the SDGs. These indicators are intended to form a bridge between the new model and the SDGs. However, given the comprehensive nature of the theory, model development, application, result acquisition, and analysis, the article's primary contribution will be in its focus on elaborating the instrument and technique, demonstrating the creation of a theoretical framework for the SDGs. Future works will showcase the application of the proposed KMEM21 method in five Brazilian organizations, members of Global Compact, to compare the achieved objectives and the results obtained with the organizations' performance and their sustainability reports.
